column7: Game Design and Technology for STEM+ Learning Collaborative
column8: This project will expand on successes from a previous HP Leadership Grant, linking real-world engineering experiences with video game design teaching methodology to provide learners virtual apprenticeships.  The Game Design and Technology Learning Collaborative, a sandbox for teaching and learning, will create and host an international platform for educating and collaborating with teachers and learners to implement this game design methodology for STEM+ education.  This will provide educators with:  ???Methodologies with examples using game theory in STEM+ education  ???Mapping game principles and examples to course content developed through this Collaborative  ???Techniques and technologies for implementing international collaboration using advanced learning experience (synchronous, semi-synchronous and asynchronous classrooms)   ???Technologies for creating student produced games into learning objects that can be reused across courses in multiple universities  ???Building blocks to extend outreach to precollege, at risk and marginalized students through existing partnerships with Learning for Life and AmeriCorps Teachers  ???A repository to host and share learner games using National University???s Applied Systems & Interoperability Research Lab (a partnership with Blade Systems Alliance)  ???An experimental 3D immersive learning environment to allow expansion and distribution of student created games    We will validate, present and publish our results extensively.

column7: Science Lab Server Farms
column8: Online learning technology promises to increase the accessibility of high quality learning materials thereby ???leveling the playing field??? for all students around the world.  However, one area where this strategy is lagging is in providing authentic laboratory science experiences. Our Remote Online Lab Network enables students to use real experimental devices via a web browser, thereby addressing many of the logistical limitations of ???hands-on??? labs. Because the labs are online 24/7, students can carry out their lab investigations from any location with Internet access, providing significantly more lab time with greater flexibility of access. We also support innovation and engagement by providing access to professional-caliber equipment that would never be feasible in secondary school classrooms.  Our network operates as an international collaborative of universities to share instrumentation with high schools to create a virtual distributed science lab.  An efficacy trial with nearly 1000 students in Fall 2009 demonstrated very significant pre/post learning gains in both science content and process skills.  Now that initial curriculum and labs have been brought online and tested, we will be building out a more complete web based portal and expanding our collaborators and range of available labs and curricula.

column3: Empire State College, State University of New York
column7: Empowering STEM Faculty for Teaching the 21st Century Student
column8: SUNY Empire State College (ESC) and St Petersburg State Polytechnical University (SPbSPU) in St. Petersburg, Russia are both innovators in their respective countries.  SUNY ESC  recently completed a three-year grant, in which fifteen online courses in math and science were developed that incorporated innovative approaches to engaging STEM learners.  SPbSPU has already been involved in a number of collaborative efforts internationally and has also received previous HP grants. One of their collaborations was with Bard College and included videoconferencing.    We propose a joint effort to improve and assess faculty development in STEM education, focusing on working with students at a distance.  Our project will engage 40 faculty from ESC and SPbSPU in a joint faculty development effort.  The effectiveness of the faculty development activities, which are based on a model of immersion of faculty into a collaborative constructive learning environment, will be assessed.  Changes in faculty self-efficacy will be measured. In addition, examples of faculty changes in their teaching strategies in subsequent teaching will be determined.  Stemming from their engagement in collaborative work in faculty development, at least two collaborative projects are expected to emerge and these will be supported by our institutions as they move forward.

column3: Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro
column7: Blended On Line Collaboration for Global Engineering Education Excellence???. A joint proposal with ???Building on the experience of the Indo US Collaborative for Engineering Education IUCEE???
column8: This project led by Indo US Collaboration for Engineering Education (IUCEE) at UMass Lowell will be a team effort along with International Federation for Engineering Education Societies (IFEES), Student Platform for Engineering Education and Development (SPEED), and Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (PUC-Rio). This team has already been active for the past three years in its efforts to improve the quality and global relevance of engineering education in many countries.     The goal of the project is to build a solid base in Engineering Education by strengthening the four pillars of education: 1) learner-centric teaching; 2) research excellence; 3) outcomes based quality and 4) innovation and entrepreneurship. This will in turn lead to collaborations and networks, which will assist in the improvement of global relevance of engineering education in the US. Leaders from IUCEE, IFEES, PUC-Rio, and SPEED have already been working on the adaptation of the IUCEE model to other countries.      The innovation proposed by this team is to research and develop models for blended on-line Student Learning Modules (SLM) for engineering students in India for the on-going IUCEE programs and start adapting this model to other countries which are members of IFEES, starting with Brazil.

column3: School of  Information,  Renmin University of China
column7: Research and Promotion of Online Collaborative Learning Education
column8: In the practice of IT education, we have recognized challenging problems such as large volume of course content, rapid update of IT techniques, obvious discrepancy of students??? expectation, lack of lecturing time etc. It is inadequate to achieve our course objectives only by lecturing in class. Actually students gain and accumulate most of their IT knowledge, skills, and practical experiences through off-class study and practices.    In collaborative learning, students learn mutually and collaboratively in helping each other and building up knowledge, skills and comprehension through communication, discussion, problem solving and projects.    We plan to apply the idea of collaborative learning to IT courses. On the supportive online learning platform, we will explore a promising online collaborative learning pattern, which would combine class lecturing with collaborative learning to tackle the foregoing challenges and improve education quality.    More courses will be involved when this way of education proves effective. The achievement and experiences from it will be shared across different institutions and instructors. More students will benefit from our IT courses on this education platform, while the course resources are open to be accessed and used by those who are interested in the courses.

column7: Remote Access to Scientific Instrumentation and Online Labs for STEM Education: Building Laboratory Parity throughout the Curriculum
column8: Lack of access to scientific instrumentation represents a significant factor in the educational divide that often exists between high schools, two and four-year institutions.  Students taking equivalent science courses (AP Chemistry, Introductory College Chemistry) have significantly different laboratory experiences based on access to and use of instrumentation.  This divide places students from instrument poor feeder institutions entering instrument rich four-year science degree programs at a significant disadvantage.  The goal of this project is to use remote instrumentation and online laboratory activities to bridge the educational divide and build laboratory parity between three institutions: Western Washington University, Whatcom Community College and Squalicum High School.  Tablet PCs will be configured to allow remote access to instrumentation routinely used in undergraduate laboratories at Western.  Whatcom and Squalicum students will use the tablets to conduct real time experiments at their home institutions that are equivalent to those experienced by Western students.  This project will build on Western???s Integrated Laboratory (ILN) initiative to provide anytime/anyplace access to instrumentation to enhance learning opportunities in the sciences.  In order to expand the project, materials from this project will be used to develop, in partnership with the Sloan-C, an online teaching certificate program with an online laboratory specialty.

column7: Implementing Virtual Laboratories and Online Learning for STEM+ Education
column8: In the proposed project, Fisk University plans to introduce online teaching technologies, including virtual labs, web-based computer simulations, webinars, audio and video lectures into Chemistry, Mathematics, and Computer Science courses.  We plan to collaborate with other HP Catalyst Multi-Versity Consortium members, including Northwestern University, Western Washington University, National University and Renmin University (China) to share online teaching experiences and resources. HP tablets, web cameras, servers and other equipment will be used to achieve the proposed objectives.

column7: Providing and Evaluating Authentic On-Line Science Laboratory Experiences through the BC-ILN
column8: A majority of smaller, rural post-secondary institutions do not have access to modern scientific instrumentation due to limitations in funding and infrastructure.  With increasing global demands for knowledge and skills in science, this places many students at a disadvantage in their literacy and proficiency with scientific instrumentation.    Through this project, the British Columbia-Integrated Laboratory Network (BC-ILN) will build on its past work to overcome the obstacles listed above by improving and developing its online laboratory offerings and support to remote locations.    The BC-ILN will:  1.Providing computers onsite at remote locations, resulting in a more effective laboratory experience;  2.Providing online general chemistry laboratories using remote analytical instrumentation to geographically isolated students   3.Assessing and optimizing the user experience for remote operation of cyber-enabled instrumentation; and  4.Developing a streamlined version of a lab exercise solely for the remote user, with accompanying faculty professional development materials.    The BC-ILN will expand the reach of its online offerings, improve STEM learning opportunities for marginalized students and disseminate their findings.  Lastly, the BC-ILN will encourage more students to enter STEM education by offering remote delivery, hands-on lab activities designed to stimulate student interest in further science education at a post-secondary level.

column7: HP Cyber Resource Central for K-16 STEM Education and Beyond
column8: The goal of project is to build an educational resource-sharing model that enables across-campus collaboration, mobile and cloud computing, remote laboratory access, and open-course adoption among a collaboration network consisting of more than 40 high schools, 2-year colleges, and universities. The collaboration network was established by the support of a current NSF grant, in which ECU is the lead institution.        The project uses both off-the-shelf and in-house developed technologies to create multiple virtual environments for learning and collaboration. With the requested HP hardware, the project will scale up to have a direct impact on more than 2000 STEM students, teachers, and instructors. The users each will have a dedicated persistent online workspace where they will be exposed to the computing resources and software applications that are unavailable at their hosting institutions. Other collaboration tools such as OpenSim virtual-world, VCL, MS Application Server, and multimedia open-course creation tools will also be hosted on the HP servers and accessed by the users from collaboration network for student project collaboration and instructor training. The outcomes from the project will be disseminated in an easily adoptable form for use in education, leading to a global impact on STEM+ education.

column7: Online Learning  with Technology+
column8: Since 2008 Moscow Gymnasia #1540 is building the online learning environment for students and teachers investigating the benefits of the blended learning model. The existing School Center for Innovations in Learning (SCIL) provides the teachers with the variety of professional development courses. The previous grant from HP was used to upgrade the existing level of using technologies at the level of STEM education and development of several new online courses.   At this time we want to contribute to the Multi-Versity Consortium our experiences in blended learning model and the innovative course ???Technology +???. The course was originally developed at our school as a  pilot course to test the new competence-based approach to teaching Technology and Engineering at the level of secondary school.   The expected result of the project is the further development of the SCIL as a training  center for other teachers from Moscow who teach STEM subjects; the organization of the online learning at the ???Technology+??? course for the wider dissemination of the best practices of teaching Technology at secondary schools.

column7: ''East-Africa - America Cyber-Collaboratory''
column8: This project is designed to demonstrate a viable and cost-effective model for cyber-collaboration between the University of East African in Baraton, UEAB, Kenya and Youngstown State University, YSU, in Ohio and their partners on both continents.  It is built upon their existing collaborations, including that with the REAL-C Collaborative, which emphasizes development and implementation of new electronic and human-factors tools to support remote access to advanced cyber-instrumentation.  The requested funds will establish the core-infrastructure at UEAB that will allow the African partners to fully participate in this e-learning/e-science collaborative and will dramatically improve the learning, teaching, and research experiences and outcomes at UEAB.  It will serve as an extensible test bed for future similar collaborations between African Universities and the partners of the REAL-C collaborative and will include both classical e-Science and e-Learning at Baraton using electronic measurements and calculations made possible with the HP infrastructure such as Math modules, Science Kits, and Computational Calculations in classes throughout all fields of science, technology, engineering and math (STEM), and also health education and agricultural sciences.  This will be done both using open source technologies for collaborative environments and commercial tools this team has/is developing with Zethus Software and Bruker-AXS.

column7: ???Blended On Line Collaboration for Global Engineering Education Excellence???
column8: The vision is to improve quality and global relevance of engineering education across the globe using blended on-line technologies. This will be a team effort between Indo US Collaboration for Engineering Education (IUCEE) at UMass Lowell, International Federation for Engineering Education Societies (IFEES), Student Platform for Engineering Education and Development (SPEED), and Pontifical University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (PUC-Rio). During the past three years, IUCEE has conducted 83 workshops with US experts for over 2,100 engineering faculty in India under IUCEE. Content for all the courses has been provided on open source portal. Videoconferencing was blended in for conducting common sessions. This blended on-line approach has greatly enhanced effectiveness. We will build on experiences from IUCEE model to demonstrate use of best practices in blended online education for students and professional development of faculty. The focus will be on developing Student Learning Modules (SLM) for use in blended online delivery of engineering diplomas. Emphasis will be in engaging students and assessing impact on learning by students. Student members of SPEED will play a key role. Relevant aspects of this model will be adapted for Brazil (PUC-Rio). Other members of the IFEES community will explore the applicability of similar approaches in their countries as well.

column7: High Performance Technology to Support ???Applying Virtual Worlds to Science Ethics Education??? (NSF Grant #0932712)
column8: In support of National Science Foundation grant #0932712 (awarded 9/2009), the current proposal is a request for funds to significantly enhance the technological capabilities of the current NSF project.  The NSF project (Ethics Education in Science and Engineering [EESE] funding) involves generating virtual world training modules that can be incorporated into advanced undergraduate and graduate-level science courses. These modules will be discipline-specific and will center on science content while raising ethical questions of various kinds, including those related to the mentor/mentee relationship in the laboratory, the examination of which contributes to the culture of the next generation of scientific researchers. The goal of the NSF grant project is to produce training modules that can facilitate ethics education for scientists by utilizing the untapped power of interactive technologies found in the virtual world of Second Life. The interactive, experiential nature of virtual learning modules, combined with the global web-based location in Second Life, enables science faculty and students to access and problem-solve complex ethical issues that are grounded in the content of their particular disciplines. This current grant request would provide the team with technology dedicated solely to the project and would enable richer, more accessible, involvement from students and faculty.

column7: High Performance Technology to Support ???Applying Virtual Worlds to Science Ethics Education???
column8: The current proposal is to support the deployment of science ethics modules at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN) utilizing an innovative high performance technology solution. The virtual world science ethics modules will be developed by collaborators at West Chester University, through their project funded under the NSF program in Ethics Education in Science and Engineering. The UKZN team will pilot these discipline-specific modules in advanced undergraduate and graduate-level science courses to raise awareness of science ethics in the South African research and teaching environment, by utilizing the untapped power of interactive technologies found in the virtual world Second Life. The interactive, experiential nature of virtual learning modules, combined with the global web-based location in Second Life, enables science faculty and students to access and problem-solve complex ethical problems that are grounded in the content of their particular discipline. The implementation of these modules at UKZN will identify ethical and technological challenges unique to the South African context; addressing these challenges will significantly enhance the global impact of this program. This current grant request would provide the UKZN team with technology dedicated solely to the project and would enable richer, more accessible, involvement from students and faculty.

column7: VRLE Lab: Virtualized and Remote Laboratory Environment for Hands-on Blended/Online Learning in Engineering and Technology Programs
column8: The goal of the proposed project is to develop a virtualized and remote laboratory environment (VRLE) that facilitates 24/7 access to laboratory equipment and computation-intensive software tools anytime, anywhere via Internet. The VRLE lab will be used to (i) deliver blended and/or online courses that support broad range of learning outcomes, (ii) improve 21st century career skills, (iii) increase qualified educators to support these education efforts, and (iv) implement innovative training/certification programs to prepare and retrain individuals for high demand careers in engineering and technology. The VRLE lab will provide a framework for instructors to author laboratory experiments, provision laboratory equipment/software, conduct assessment, and maximize resource utilization. Students can reserve/schedule lab time, and gain high-fidelity laboratory experience through interactive media-rich course/lab material and remote interaction with real laboratory equipment ?¢Ê°∞ running real software. The VRLE lab facility will be made available to consortia members, thereby developing community support for instructors and students. The project team believes that the proposed ?¢Ê©´Multi Versity?¢Êù project has potential to serve as a model for other minority institutions in delivering web-accessible programs that are resource intensive (laboratory/computation) overcoming geographic boundaries. The project results/impact will be disseminated through workshops, conferences, project webpage/videos, and technical/educational journals.

column7: Stellenbosch Connected: Empowering lecturers and engaging students through Tablet PCs
column8: The project, based at Stellenbosch University, aims to develop good practice models of blended learning through the incorporation of tablet PCs in teaching and learning, thereby contributing to student engagement and success. The tablets, used in conjunction with systems for audience response, podcasting, online communication and classroom participation, will empower lecturers to use technology and document their practice. The project incorporates the following elements: lecturers in three STEM faculties apply to their Deans, with written motivations indicating how they will use the tablets, out of which a team of 60 participants in this renewal project will be selected; they will receive training from the Centre for Teaching and Learning and the IT division on the use of the machines as well as on how to encourage student engagement in the classroom; lecturers will evaluate their use of the tablets at the end of the year; a conference on good practice involving all 60 lecturers will be held; and selected lecturers will be awarded a trip to an international conference. The support team and selected lecturers will write up the findings for local and international publications. The project forms part of a broader IT and curriculum renewal emphasis at the university.

column3: Graduate School of Education, University of Bristol
column7: E-scapes
column8: The digital world is being driven by emerging communities of people, and these communities will shape the future. This is the focus of STEM+ and this proposal will consider the theory and practice of Pedagogy 3.0 from the viewpoints of initial teacher trainees in Science from the University of Bristol, working with secondary schools and the broader educational community.   ?¢”  The original vision of ???distance learning??? was of electronic resources that could substitute for the role of the teacher. The specialist subject knowledge and pedagogical expertise of the teacher could be replaced by non-linear hyperlinked multimedia courses. We will reinvent this concept by creating a new generation of materials called 'e-scapes'. These will place the teacher at the heart of the project, and will redefine the roles of teachers, students, interactive project work and classrooms. Teachers will collaborate with students to author the materials. Students can be experimental scientists carrying out practical work, processing, debating and arguing their conclusions. They can be researchers, authors, film makers, animators, interviewers, broadcasters. They can share their thoughts with schools and with professional scientists locally or anywhere in the world. Everywhere is global and everywhere is now.

column7: Using Technology to Support Teacher and Student Conceptual Learning in Mathematics and Science
column8: The mathematics and science educators from the Department of Educational Communication and Technology at Kenyatta University near Nairobi, Kenya will work with colleagues from the Departments of Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics at Kenyatta University and mathematics and science education colleagues from Syracuse University, California State University???Fullerton, and California State University???San Marcos to address the following challenges through this project:    ???Teachers in Kenya have limited information technology (IT) skills.  ???Teachers in Kenya lack deep and connected content and pedagogical content knowledge.  ???There is no link in Kenya between preservice teachers??? preparation and teachers??? work in schools allowing for coordinated monitoring of induction and professional development.    and to explore the following research question:    ???In what ways can technology support teachers in ???unpacking??? mathematical and scientific knowledge for teaching?    Through the HP Catalyst Initiative, we propose to work with approximately 300 preservice mathematics and science teachers, as well as approximately eight inservice mathematics and science teachers at two nearby high schools, through a series of workshops to teach them how to use computer technology in their instructional planning and how to integrate HP MCL Science Probe Kits and HP Graphing Calculators technology into their teaching.  During the two years of the project, these teachers will use technology-rich tasks with approximately 960 secondary students.

column7: Virtual Exchange Program: Connecting, Collaborating and Constructing STEM+ Learning
column8: Virtual Exchange Program seeks to address the persistent challenge of helping students integrate content between their classes in STEM fields and other disciplines, as well as between school and their lives. Its aim is to improve pedagogy and the classroom experience by educating preservice and inservice teachers in Southern California and India to be interdisciplinary leaders in their schools, districts and profession, thereby helping their own students and influencing the preservice teachers following after them.  Rather than isolating teachers along disciplinary lines, it will train teachers from all subjects together in the basics of interdisciplinary, project-based inquiry learning and demonstrating how the pedagogy can improve student transfer of learning. Designed to dissolve boundaries, it will utilize technology to mobilize educational professionals across multiple tiers, disciplines--and countries--to develop a way of teaching that is multicultural, inherently connective and that encourages students to be both creative and analytical; students will also communicate and collaborate over the Web. It is a partnership of the California Academy of Mathematics and Science (CAMS), a specialized public high school, and California State University, Dominguez Hills, on whose campus CAMS is located, in collaboration with two teacher colleges and secondary schools in India.

column7: ???Inter-teaching???: Developing dialogic approaches to STEM+ education through digital practitioner networks
column8: ???Inter-teaching??? examines two emerging areas of significance in teacher education:     1) ???practitioner research networks??? as a methodology in pre-service teacher education;   2) online social networks as support for pre-service teacher education.      The main aim is to enable new STEM teachers to explore and develop new pedagogical opportunities using new technology through conducting practitioner research within a supportive, collaborative and networked environment.     The project will develop guidance on improving inquiry-based STEM+ education by engaging pre-service teachers in practitioner research networks focused on exploring new technologies.     It will produce research evidence showing how technology can be used for meaningful, inquiry-based STEM+ teaching and learning.    ???Inter-teaching??? is envisaged as a circuit of classroom interventions and research methodology facilitated by network technology, utilizing a bespoke practitioner social network in order to:    - Bring together a collaborative team of experts to design inquiry-based STEM+ classroom interventions    - Create student teacher practitioner research networks to trial and evaluate inquiry-based STEM+ classroom interventions    - Build a knowledge base and repository of technology-supported STEM+ activities that can be sustained beyond the duration of the programme, or repeated and replicated in other settings    - Collaborate with Futurelab on the STEMlab initiative to develop sustainable resources and practices that can be widely disseminated using the online map of educational innovation, the EducationEye

column7: Design Corps
column8: Design Corps is a participatory national program that inspires teachers and students to excel in new methods for exploring STEM concepts by creating challenge-based learning projects???immersing teachers and students in a collaborative process that requires the adoption of new ???roles??? of teacher facilitated, student-driven enquiry/design. Students learn game development in STEM content, from design to production, along with programming and media production. Teachers??? growth in this new pedagogy is supported through a robust syllabus of learning experiences facilitated by experts at the Learning Games Network???a non-profit organization comprised of leading researchers, designers, teachers and students in the field of digital games for learning.    Partnering with the state of Kentucky, Design Corps will be embedded into their statewide Student Technology Leadership Program, which supports teachers and students in conducting technology/project-based learning. Researchers at the University of Kentucky???s P20 Innovation Lab will study the effectiveness of this approach and pedagogy. Leading a team of 25 teacher-researchers known as the ''Kentucky Game-Changers'' who will serve as the are leading the on-the-ground catalysts and action researchers for this project, the research team will study the impact of this approach and how it relates to existing statewide efforts to refine and scale pre-service and in-service teacher training on new STEM pedagogical approaches.

column7: Future Learning Environments
column8: The project ???Future Learning Environments??? will build a network of research partners and user organizations in order to research the interdependencies of learning models, room and ambiance design patterns, furnitures, room climate, room zoning and communication facilities, tool- as well as media usage in order to reach the best learning effects. Additionally the network will work on innovative business models and organizational schemes, that focus on sustainability and adaptibility. The project will establish a network of research partners cooperating within a year-by-year scheme where the research questions and topics are defined in common. The network is about to start November 2010 and will start with a substantial learners survey as well as the definition of future holistic scenarios how learning environments of the future may look like. One of the most interesting questions of the networks research will be the interplay and the interdependence of real and virtual learning environments in their complementary and synergetic design as well as in their consequences for the quantitive and qualitative need for room and space. ???Online-onsite-Integration??? is a key question.  The network shall deliver practical guidelines to create modern and innovative, learner-centered learning environments and will build up practical examples with selected members of the network

column7: Computer Supported Collaborative Science
column8: The Computer Supported Collaborative Science (CSCS) initiative is an ongoing effort to help science teachers engage students in authentic research experiences through the use of cloud based computing tools.  Faculty from CSUN developed the CSCS model and training program.  In the first CSCS training in the summer of 2010, 20 middle school science teachers from high-need schools gathered for 8 days to learn how to integrate technology into quality science activities.  In this ?¢Ê©´Google bootcamp,?¢Êù teachers learned to use Google tools to gather data and collaborate on the analysis of this data as well as assess knowledge gain.  We are requesting technology sufficient to accommodate four mobile computer labs.  Three sets of notebooks will be loaned to teachers trained at the Google bootcamp whose classrooms do not have sufficient technology (about one-third of the teachers reported not being able to fully implement CSCS because they lacked student computers for the science lab.) A fourth mobile lab would be used on the CSUN campus in the summer Google bootcamp and during the academic year in Bio102 (a science course for preservice teachers).  Our international partner will be FutureLab in the United Kingdom.  We will offer professional development to consortium partners via SKYPE on the CSCS model.

column7: Kingston Primary School Intern Project
column8: The Kingston Primary School(KPS) STEM proposal involves taking the Kingston Internship model, arguably the most innovative and effective pre-service teacher training in Australia, to geographically remote regions of Western Australia and link with Partner schools in USA and China. KPS in partnership with Edith Cowan University School of Education (Mt Lawley and Bunbury campuses) have developed a Professional Learning model where pre-service teachers spend the final year of their degree with a highly skilled mentor teacher in the school setting. After their Internship year they are placed in rural Western Australia for two years, teaching in isolated, low socio-economic and disadvantaged communities with high percentages of indigenous students.    Through the use of virtual rooms situated in Kingston and Edith Cowan University, these highly sought after graduates will be able to continue to access and deliver high quality professional development and assistance by linking with other Interns and Mentors around the state. Eight teachers from Kingston have mentored teachers at Jiaxing No1 Middle School in China, and two administrators have presented at the Professional Development School Conference in Orlando Florida, 2010.  These international links will be further enhanced, linking our partner teachers in these countries. Mentor Teachers and Intern Teachers would use HP Slate technology to demonstrate lessons in real time as well as prepare PD sessions.

column7: CAPACITY BUILDING OF STEM+ TEACHERS FOR EFFECTIVE DELIVERY OF STEM+ DISCILPINES FRO THE 21ST CENTURY
column8: High priority has been given to STEM Education policies the world over. Research reports indicate that students perceive some STEM concepts as abstract and difficult. STEM teachers also perceive some concepts as difficult to teach. There is a fundamental problem for both the STEM students and teachers for any meaningful progress to be made in STEM Education.  STEM Education at the tertiary level has failed to equip learners with the skills required for survival in a modern knowledge economy. Employers complain that tertiary institutions are producing unemployable graduates. The problem with STEM Education is connected with the method of delivery where content is separated from pedagogy. The Nigerian STEM Education community is going through a vicious cycle which needs to be broken for STEM Education to be improved. This can be done at the teacher preparation level, through the provision of appropriate modern technologies that can facilitate better teaching and learning, and enhance communication and collaboration among STEM teachers, practitioners and students. Due to the low collaboration among STEM specialists and STEM Educators, there is a major gap between content knowledge and pedagogic knowledge. The intention therefore is to use modern ICT facilities to attempt to bridge the gap between content and pedagogic knowledge so that STEM students and Faculty will acquire needed pedagogic content knowledge.

column3: School of Mathematical Sciences of Beijing Normal University
column7: Using Mathematical Technology to Help Students Get Access to Powerful Mathematical Ideas: The Role of Constituting Learning Community of Mathematics Teachers
column8: Funding agencies including HP have invested heavily in ambitious agendas for technology issue in middle school mathematics. Since 2007, our research group have worked with HP on a longitudinal research called ?¢Ê©´the Integration of Handed Technology and Middle School Mathematics Curriculum?¢Êù , which impacted 20 experimental school districts and more than 200 experimental schools around China-mainland ,supported by HP.   We have got much more ideas about the how importance of technology issues in the instruction of middle school mathematics and also many active instructional cases. So, we are very be confident of that mathematical technology (especially, the Graph Calculator) is a very powerful medium that help students get access to powerful mathematical ideas.        Now, what confront us is how to implement these ideas in classroom instruction and that help students get access to big mathematical ideas. Based on another collaborative research project with Vanderbilt University, we notice that building learning community focusing on ambitious instructional practice for mathematics teachers is a very effective strategy to enhance students?¢Ê¢‚ mathematical learning at scales.   So, we argue that our initial idea about the use of the technology (such as Graph Calculator ) will play an important role in help student get a deep understanding of mathematics and building effective learning community focusing on the use of mathematical technology should be valued

column7: Early Career mentoring for mathematics and science teachers using digital technology.
column8: The project will build on the work of the existing Starting Out mentoring  programme that aims to improve retention of teachers in maths and science.  Starting Out is a ??1.2M two year pilot programme  funded by the Training and Development Agency for schools, an arm of Government responsible for the initial and in-service training of teachers and other school staff in England.    The programme is one of the most successful national mentoring programmes for teachers in the UK and is now supporting over 650 maths and science teachers.    Through the STEM + project we will use HP technology to foster collaboration between new teachers and experienced professionals to work on small pieces of action research we call ???inquiries??? (See Annex 1 for an exemplar inquiry).  The inquiries are a successful part of the existing Starting Out programme, and are similar to those used by the United States NSTA science teacher mentoring scheme.      The new teachers, or mentees, will work in networks to investigate three inquiries.  The inquiries will focus on developing and evaluating innovative pedagogical approaches based on the use of HP technology available in the bid.  They will also be able to share their growing expertise in these areas with the departments they work with in school.

column7: GoNAUTeach ??? Geospatial Outreach for NAUTeach
column8: The Center for Science Teaching and Learning at Northern Arizona University is poised to develop new pedagogy that bridges pre-service, mentor teachers, faculty, and geospatial technology to engage students in project-based instruction leading to 21st century skills development through the HP Catalyst Initiative ???Pedagogy 3.0??? consortium. Our aim is to prepare NAUTeach pre-service teachers to use geographic information systems (GIS) and problem based instruction as tools in the classroom, working with mentor teachers who have recently attended professional development to implement geospatial technology into their classrooms. We have the ability to leverage existing projects to build a program that is sustainable, research-based and attractive to schools and communities. Creating and implementing technology-integrated lessons would be incorporated into the current NAUTeach coursework requirement, but access to technology limits our capacity to develop this program. Our vision is to create mobile computer labs and training opportunities to support these efforts - GoNAUTeach ??? Geospatial Outreach to NAUTeach. Mobile labs will ensure teachers have access to geospatial technology for pre-service teachers to observe and utilize in their apprentice teaching, and provide tools for secondary students to gather data in the field and classroom. HP technology will make this effort truly sustainable and innovative.

column7: Learning to create a better built environment: Activity led learning with information and communication technology for a 21st century collaborative global education
column8: This proposal describes activities to be conducted at the Department of Built Environment at Coventry University (CU-DBE) in conjunction with activities proposed by the Pacific Northwest Center for Construction Education and Research at University of Washington (UW-PNCCER) (a ???joined??? proposal). We will use HP-provided technology to support and enhance the two institution???s convergent teaching vision relying on the common leitmotif of Activity Led Learning (ALL). CU-DBE and UW-PNCCER are leading efforts to embed ALL concepts into curriculum for the built environment (BE) disciplines (i.e. Architecture, Engineering and Construction). column7: Hands-on information technology virtual laboratory powered by cloud computing for global collaboration
column8: The speed of scientific and technological advances, along with resource constraints makes it very difficult for academic institutions to maintain technical currency in instructional labs.  Information and distributed computing technologies (IDCT) make it possible to share computing capacity and deliver remote hands-on learning experiences effectively and efficiently. IDCT also brings unprecedented collaborative opportunities to bridge the digital divide in STEM education not only between well-equipped schools and less-funded schools, but also between developed countries and developing countries.     To that end, we are proposing a project that will integrate virtualization and cloud technologies with HP equipment to provide concrete online learning experiences to students worldwide.  This will, among other things, allow us to    1. demonstrate setting up low-cost, open source, cloud infrastructures such as Virtual Computing Lab (VCL) in local schools or colleges;   2. create custom virtual environments and hands-on information technology lab modules which can be hosted on cloud/grid computing networks; and  3. evaluate different collaborative tools such as VNC, RDP, and FreeNX for educational purposes in cloud computing environments.     The project will leverage existing or new cloud computing networks and build a repository of virtual environments to share among faculty and students in secondary and tertiary educational institutions globally.

column7: The Challenge of Water Quality:  China and United States ???Sister Schools??? Seek Solutions Together
column8: This project builds upon Stamford???s HP Innovation in Education Grant, a multi-disciplinary project involving students in real-world analysis of groundwater, using current technology to track and analyze data, creating maps and graphs that demonstrate findings.  Students obtain results using national protocols, learning about factors influencing the availability and quality of water, topography; and drainage, flora; & fauna and the impact of urban development. Working with a number of community organizations, they meet scientists and learn about their careers.      Through its Chinese sister school, Shandong University Middle School, Scofield hopes to bring an international focus to the problem of water quality. Shandong also face significant water quality issues -- Shandong Province (Huangshui River Basin) is recognized as one of the most polluted river systems in China.  As in Stamford, much of this problem is a result of a fast growing population, industrial growth and agriculture.  Crucial points are water availability, pollution of water resources, and inadequate sewage treatment.      Through sharing the results of Stamford???s research and city resources with their sister school and teaching them to do their own analysis through videos and web-based contacts, it is hoped that both communities can learn and help to solve these community problems.

column3: Cairo University - Faculty of Computers and Information
column7: Cairo Cloud Computer
column8: This project aims to develop a cloud computing lab for educational and research purposes at the Faculty of Computers and Information, Cairo University. The specific aim of this lab is to provide a cloud computing environment that serves the following goals:    (1)A test-bed for teaching basic and computationally-intensive computer science courses using cloud computing. This will allow students to access various virtual computing resources as needed for their classes with varying computing power. In particular we want to explore how basic and advanced computer science courses can benefit from cloud computing.    (2)A test-bed for cloud computing training and research. Graduation and research projects will be conducted on various cloud computing aspects and on collaboratively solving pressing African developmental problems that can benefit from cloud computing power.     (3)Training courses will be offered to academic and industrial personnel in different parts of Egypt and hopefully Africa using the power of cloud computing.    (4)With this cloud computing Lab., Cairo University can join forces with similar efforts in Egypt and Africa to develop a super cloud that can utilized by researchers of the participating members from virtually anywhere .

column7: Thinking Global???Acting Local: Engaging Learners in Geospatial Technology Projects through the HP Collaboratory
column8: This partnership will join Hispanic students from Genesis Academy in Phoenix Arizona with Moody High School in Corpus Christi Texas and GeoTech at Del Mar to share innovative curriculum and service-learning projects in their local neighbourhoods with a global perspective.  The GeoTech Center will provide technical expertise and support for the teachers and students at the two partner high schools.  The Genesis Academy will use existing data from the Arizona Department of Health to map, analyze, and study the rates of immunization among youth in the state of Arizona.  By doing so, the participating members of the Immunizers can begin to do draw precise conclusions as to why residents decide whether to get their children immunized.   Critical analysis can be made based on income levels, level of education attainment, proximity to healthcare institutions, and exposure to infectious diseases.  The Innovation Academy for Engineering, Environmental and Marine Science at Moody will incorporate the GIS/HP partnership project into the 9th grade curriculum in World Geography and Advanced Placement Human Geography.  Through the use of equipment, the inquiry based learning projects that involve cross-curriculum applications in Math, Science, English, and technology classes will be benefit from inclusion of data generated from GIS applications.

column3: Masinde Muliro University of Science and Technology
column7: Development of an East African computational chemistry infrastructure at Masinde Muliro University of Science and technology
column8: The proposed project suggests development of a core expertise in computational chemistry in East Aftrica by exploring how to best use collaborative online learning to address two urgent social challenges: (1) mitigation of environmental toxins, and (2) Development of antimalarial natural products. The project further suggests development of a grid service infrastructure for computational chemistry that links to computing resources at partner institutions such as Binghamton University. Through the grid Learners and researchers at MMUST and partner institutions will have access to otherwise expensive computational chemistry resources at Binghamton University including programs such as QCHEM, GAMES GROMACS among others. This will enable investigation of materials that may be too difficult to find or too expensive to purchase. The infrastructure will be linked to the brain gain e-infrastructure project of which the university is a participant. It will be developed over two academic years by teaching developed computational chemistry courses and creating a computational chemistry resource website that will be part of the university e-waste for Brain gain project site found at www.ewaste.co.ke.

column7: Learning to Create Sustainable Built Environments: Experiential and Contextual Learning (ECL) with Information and Communication Technology for a 21st Century Collaborative Global Education
column8: STEM+ students undergo coursework where concepts are often divorced from the complexities of real-world situations (i.e. Knowledge De-contextualization). Consequently, students struggle applying fundamental concepts for solving problems. Our efforts to embed experiential and contextual learning (ECL) concepts into curricula for Built Environment (BE) disciplines aim at addressing Knowledge De-contextualization and its consequences.   Emerging BE educational trends are focused on grand challenges of this century, including Urbanization, Globalization and Sustainability. Using ECL to relate concepts to challenges, we seek to explore how cloud computing (1) supports global collaboration; (2) facilitates ECL on UGS challenges; and (3) improves retention and recruitment of marginalized students in STEM+ disciplines.   An HP award will galvanize ECL at the Pacific Northwest Center for Construction Research and Education at University of Washington, whose affiliated faculty have several current and pending grants that will benefit from such award. The Center for Experiential Learning is a leader in ECL research and implementation whereas the Center for Instructional Development and Research is leading assessment of ECL. By leveraging this local UW expertise and connecting to Global Collaboratories, the benefits from this project are far-reaching as we seek to disseminate technology-supported learning methodologies to other secondary and tertiary institutions.

column7: Development Active Learner-Centered Online Environment for Collaborative Problem Solving For Computer Science and Information Technology Undergraduate Students in Kenya
column8: Information and Communication Technologies are increasingly being recognized as essential tools of development???tools that can empower the marginalized, enhance skills, increase productivity, and create new opportunities in learning and research ecosystems. The success of ICT-enabled development will not only be measured by the diffusion of technology, but by advances in development itself: economic growth, education and ultimately, achievement of the Millennium Development Goals especially in developing economies.  STEM+ undergraduate students in many developing economies are disadvantaged because of the negative effects of underdevelopment and the ???digital divide???. Despite recent improvements of the ICT infrastructure and increased investment in ICT by universities, the benefits of shared collaboration, improved learning experience, exchange of ideas and transfer of ???21st century skills??? have not been realized. High teacher/student ratios and poor pedagogy and delivery at this level have exacerbated this situation.  This Research project aims to explore new opportunities that will leverage on the experience of more developed online education environments modeled on active learner centered pedagogy. The project will implement an online eLearning environment that supports problem based collaboration between faculty and students. The eLearning platform and other resources will be accessible through the web and mobile platforms. The project will involve 2nd year and 3rd year undergraduate students taking computer science or Information technology degree programs at Strathmore University.

column7: Learning to create a better built environment: Activity Led Learning with information and communication technology for a 21st century collaborative global education

column7: STEM???Science, Technology, Enigneering, Math,-----Systemic, Topical, Environmental, &  Monumental!!!
column8: With the international recognition of the W-I-N-S Team, a 30 million dollar renovation of our local high school focusing on STEM, and resources such as the University of Rhode Island School of Oceanography and the Metropolitan Learning Center, our consortia is eager to partner with the Meraka Institute. column7: Mobile grid platform for STEM subjects social learning and knowledge measurement  (MoPS)
column8: We propose the creation of a new education and knowledge measurement model using mobile devices and social networking techniques (MoPS). This model will utilize people???s tendency to simplify usage of IT, to be socially involved and to collaborate across the globe. We team up with Irkutsk State Technical University to develop and test mobile collaboration platform. The aim of this platform is to create informal education communities to distribute STEM knowledge among students. We will be focusing on field testing and educational module for geosciences to approve practical usefullness of our ideas and technologies.  MoPS users will bring up geological problems (for example field data interpretation) using their mobile devices. Such problems will be distributed among user???s peers (known as friends in social networks), which can redistribute it further for detailed analysis and suggestions. The user who receives the problem can respond or start the discussion among community members. Such collaborative environment will increase learning motivation by setting learning objectives. Active leaders of the community will provide incentives for others. This learning approach is similar to what is happening in modern enterprises and research centers. It will allow students to get practical experience in learning how to learn.

column7: Reaching the World, Mapping the Mind: Global STEM+ Collaborations between College Study-Abroad Students, At-Risk Youth, Pre-Service Educators and Career Teachers
column8: A recent policy brief from the National Education Association asserts that ???the 21st century isn???t coming; it???s already here... column7: STEM+ Innovations for under-represented rural-based schools
column8: The University of Fort Hare supports rural-based and under-represented schools where chalk-board system is the only means to teach. We received 2009 HP Grant in Education Innovation worth $100 000 to enhance our support of projects we do for these schools. The targeted students have the potential just like their urban area counterparts but lack resources and exposure to technological laboratory equipment to enable them to pursue science and technology degrees. The lack of this exposure limits them to obtain marks for direct-entry into the tertiary levels. Being able to enhance and initiate STEM+ technology innovations to these schools addresses the shortage of engineers and scientists and unveils their hidden talents. Our ultimate goal is to have a multi-media centre and produce scientists who will be job-creators rather than job-seekers.

column7: Virtual Laboratory for Engineering and Applied Sciences Education (EASE)
column8: The purpose of this collaborative effort is to transform the way engineering students are educated by creating a unique set of virtual reality laboratory experiments that provide an instructional scaffolding.  At first, the structured module will provide the student with the necessary support to comprehend new concepts.  The first experiments are prearranged, yet they are also interactive, then more 'explorative' modules that move the student from the guided to self-guided exploration. This progressive lab will be used in sophomore engineering courses in schools nationally and internationally and in a modified form in secondary schools.  It is planned for use for online and distant education as well.  The 3D virtual laboratory we develop to provide this scaffolding, will elevate the student into higher levels of involvement and interaction.  The modules will allow for a great deal of interaction with students, and as the level of involvement is increased, choice of elective, self-planned experiments.   The modules will be developed for easy adaptation and dissemination to collaborators and consortium partners.  Our goal is to reach diverse populations at a variety of sites including a research university, community colleges, secondary education institutes and informal educational sites such as museums, and international institutions.

column7: BLADE ??? Building learning as a distributed experience
column8: BLADE will involve c.400 14-19 students and 20 teachers from 12 institutions in Sheffield???s Diploma consortium for STEM+ disciplines and will impact wider practice in STEM+.   Integrated focus on Engineering, Manufacturing, IT and Creative Media reflects our vision that 21st century employment will demand experience of end-to-end skills and technologies across the ???design-to-delivery??? product lifecycle, using IT and creative media (e.g. CAD, visualization, animation) as ???glue??? technologies.      This is synergistic with Sheffield???s ambition to create a Virtual Technical Academy (an advanced application of government policy) for applied STEM+ learning, serving the traditions and high growth industries in our city-region economy ??? notably design, engineering and manufacture for medicine, assisted living and sport.    BLADE will involve distributed projects and specialist learning which breaks down arbitrary barriers of discipline (e.g. Engineering / IT / Creative Media), learning style (formal / informal) and location (across Sheffield and beyond), enabled by pervasive connectivity (our super-fast ???Digital Region??? infrastructure), personal mobile platforms, shared repositories, high quality telepresence and visualisation.     Building on our existing momentum and informed by international partnership, BLADE will escalate our investment, allowing us to develop strategies for formal and informal learning that combine STEM+ domain expertise with underpinning C21 skills, positioning learning as a lifelong opportunity in the digital realm.

column7: The Ringtones Student-Designed Learning Content for Mobile Devices Project
column8: India recently announced imminent availability of: a $35, educational e-slate and national 3G connectivity. Using these resources, marginalized students may soon use e-slates as a powerful tool and connector for lifelong learning. This project, proposed by the ISTE affiliate in India, Indian Council for Integral Education (ICIE), builds on existing collaborations with two educational groups: one in rural village schools in Tamil Nadu and one in urban slums of Mumbai. Student-participants will develop content for mobile devices in their local language,  reflecting local content and values. Formal and informal learning environments will support students as they develop these resources for themselves and their communities.    Students who are motivated, but restricted by current educational limitations, will have the possibility to improve their learning as they develop technology skills in a collaborative, cross-cultural, connected, project-based environment. The material support from this grant, membership in the New Learner Consortium, organizations of volunteer facilitators, and international resources of technology-using educators will merge in this project, informing models for future grassroots, culturally-appropriate technology integration in developing nations.

column7: Promoting Interest Through the Use of Digital Literacy & 3D Gaming
column8: The goal of this project is to design, develop, and test innovative curriculum materials and models for high-school science courses.  This proposed project, will seek to develop models for game experiences that emphasize science literacy (E-reading), computational thinking, exploratory learning and industry collaboration.  These models will address, but not be limited to, issues of: 1) formulating design strategies for games that maintain the motivational elements of creativity, exploration, problem solving and being fun to play while at the same time satisfying curriculum objectives; 2) integrating gaming into the learning experience focusing on questions of how, where and when to use games; 3) providing methodologies for connecting and applying the STEM skills learned from the gaming experiences to specific problems, and 4) leveraging industry collaboration.  The effectiveness of these models will be demonstrated through the creation and application of a 3D 3rd-person exploratory game.  Additionally, industry partners will contribute to the game?¢Ê¢‚s content and mechanics, as well as act as mentors for students involved in the learning experience.

column7: Get Invested: Case Studies in Innovation
column8: Get Invested envisions a dynamic cross cultural interface between formal and informal learning systems focusing on global challenges to inspire marginalized students?¢Ê¢‚ interest and achievement in engineering, math, and science. Linking students attending vocational programs and traditional school in San Jose, CA and Monterrey, Mexico, Get Invested exposes students from diverse cultures to creative STEM+ problem-solving with multi-media applications and multi-modality learning approaches. A replicable, scalable model that meets the needs of differentiated learners, Get Invested builds 21st Century skills by providing scaffolding for strategic thinking and communication. Working in parallel, students in San Jose and Monterrey collaborate in teams to identify a global problem or need, and envision a technology-based creative solution or product through research from CHM?¢Ê¢‚s vast resources. Students craft written proposals and oral presentations to compete for funding from teachers and CHM educators who role-play venture capitalists. CHM?¢Ê¢‚s inclusion in The New Learner consortium will contribute valuable STEM+ education outcomes concerning knowledge, skills, and attitudes transmitted outside of school, with potentially long-lasting rewards.

column7: AxS 2 STEM

column7: Eco-Virtual Environment Project- Creating a sustainable virtual world of learning
column8: The EVE Project aims to engage staff and students in the development of an exciting 3D virtual world that liberates students in their investigation of STEM based  projects. column7: Using machine learning to measure student learning
column8: For students from backgrounds that were excluded from formal learning in the past ??? such as many from the Historically Disadvantaged communities of South Africa ??? the path to STEM+ excellence is steep. During modules of the ???Extended programme??? at our university, which prepare students for undergraduate studies, electronic courseware will be instrumented to measure ??? and subsequently improve - the ways in which students utilize various resources in tutorial sessions. Clustering will be used to extract meaningful groups of student behaviors; classifiers will be designed and analyzed to determine student behaviors that predict successful learning, and outputs from these analyses will be used to suggest learning interventions. The proposed work will extend current research of our Counseling Psychology department on ''the first year student experience in SET learning''. column7: Measuring Learning in STEM+ Classrooms Using Tablet PCs for Real-Time Formative Assessment at an Engineering University: Diverse Explorations to  A.) Establish Best Practices for Enhancing Learning, and  B.) Nurture and Assess Creativity and Innovation
column8: For 6 years, our team at Mines has investigated how to enhance STEM+ education by using tablet PCs to facilitate real-time formative assessment in classrooms (???Tablet Model???). column7: Real-Time Assessment of Standards-Based Declarative & Procedural Knowledge of Students

column3: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
column7: A Quality-Aware Evaluation System for STEM+ Education
column8: The rapid proliferation of information technologies (IT) such as Internet and software development has raised great changes to teachers' teaching and students' learning styles. For example, teachers can nowadays obtain various course-related resources (e.g., e-books, texts, audios, and videos) from the Internet, and prepare for new course materials by referring to these resources; students can benefit from learning software, study abundant materials provided by teachers, and grasp the knowledge in e-learning environments; further, teachers and students can also have fast interactions after classes through forum discussions, online quiz, or Q/A via emails. Although this educational style has brought about lots of conveniences to both teaching and learning, the quality of such an educational process is however nontrivial to model, quantify, and control. Traditional paper examinations may test but not fully reveal the weak points of the teaching/learning, and these results are usually too late for teachers to remedy their teaching plans, specifically for students. Addressing the needs for evaluating and improving the quality of education, this project aims to model the course, teaching, and learning qualities. The proposed solutions can help teachers get real-time feedbacks, and adaptively revise course designs/teaching schedules so as to raise the attainment of STEM+ learners.

column7: Mathematics Partnering with Computer Science to Improve Calculus Instruction and Learning   (NSF CCLI-II 2008-2011)
column8: Pen-technology motivated the construction of a large database of student work in Calculus, both inked and scanned, through which the tagging and analysis of student errors and problem-solving strategies becomes possible. column7: Assessing STEM+ Competencies with the RosE Portfolio System
column8: Assessing STEM+ Competencies with the RosE Portfolio System will address two significant challenges in the field of STEM+ education:  1) evaluation of STEM+ competencies???teamwork, ethics, communication, cultural and global awareness???by STEM faculty; and 2) development of an efficient assessment system that produces meaningful data for guiding improvements in student learning and faculty teaching. column7: Real-Time Assessment of STEM+ Competencies Using Tablet PCs and Collaborative-Immersive Technology
column8: As a member of the Measuring Learning consortium, we are proposing to use Tablet PCs with collaborative-interactive software to perform real-time assessment of STEM+ competencies. The traditional method of assessing student learning, in which feedback is given after the learning has taken place, is an outdated model in which the emphasis is on evaluation of performance, as opposed to guidance of learning or mastery of concepts. Building on our prior work with Tablet PCs and collaborative-interactive software, we will develop new assessment tools and processes to allow for student self-assessment and faculty diagnosis of student learning needs. This dynamic ongoing assessment will capture learning and teaching while it is in process, allowing for adjustment to ensure optimal development of learners and reflective practices of educators. The overall goal of this work is to develop methods of using technology-enabled assessment to improve decision making related to instruction and in turn promote the achievement of the STEM+ competencies. This work will be performed at Grove City College and in collaboration with our global partners at institutions in France, Brazil, and China. column7: Developing innovative and authentic assessments for online, competency-based science programs
